experiment_title: Illumina HiSeq 4000 paired end sequencing: RNA-seq of human Barrett's oesophagus and oesophageal adenocarcinoma samples
study_title: RNA-seq of human Barrett's oesophagus and oesophageal adenocarcinoma samples
sample_description: Protocols: Barrett's oesophagus and OAC tissue were collected from routine endoscopies and placed into RNALater (Qiagen) and stored at -80degC. Biopsies were minced with a scalpel and RNA was extracted using RNeasy kit (Qiagen). RNA-seq libraries were constructed using Illumina TruSeq Stranded mRNA kit.

experiment_title: NextSeq 500 sequencing: GSM6914628: s7, scRNAseq Homo sapiens RNA-Seq
study_title: The single cell transcriptional landscape of esophageal adenocarcinoma and its modulation by neoadjuvant chemotherapy
project_name: The single cell transcriptional landscape of esophageal adenocarcinoma and its modulation by neoadjuvant chemotherapy
description: NextSeq 500 sequencing: GSM6914628: s7, scRNAseq Homo sapiens RNA-Seq
library_construction_protocol: PI was added prior to sorting to exclude non-viable cells. Live CD45+ and CD45- populations were sorted and adjusted to 1 x 103/ml. Samples with >85% cell viability were processed at the Genomics Birmingham Sequencing Facility (University of Birmingham, UK) for gene expression profiling using the 10X Genomics platform. Around 1.7 x 104 cells per sample were processed using the Chromium Controller (10X Genomics) for a recovery of 1 x 104 cells per sample, and library preparation was performed using the Chromium Single Cell 3′ Library & Gel Bead Kit v2 according to manufacturer's instructions. Library quantification and quality control was performed using TapeStation (Agilent). Samples were sequenced on an Illumina NextSeq 500 (150 bps, paired-end) at a sequencing depth of >50,000 raw reads/cell. Illumina NextSeq 500 (150 bps, paired-end) at a sequencing depth of >50,000 raw reads/cell.

Around 1.7 x 104 cells per sample were processed using the Chromium Controller (10X Genomics) for a recovery of 1 x 104 cells per sample, and library preparation was performed using the Chromium Single Cell 3′ Library & Gel Bead Kit v2 according to manufacturer's instructions. Library quantification and quality control was performed using TapeStation (Agilent). Samples were sequenced on an Illumina NextSeq 500 (150 bps, paired-end) at a sequencing depth of >50,000 raw reads/cell. Illumina NextSeq 500 (150 bps, paired-end) at a sequencing depth of >50,000 raw reads/cell.

experiment_title: Illumina HiSeq 2500 paired end sequencing: Whole transcriptome profiling of Esophageal adenocarcinoma and Barrett's
study_title: Whole transcriptome profiling of Esophageal adenocarcinoma and Barrett's
sample_description: Protocols: The NSq, BE, LGD tissue samples were collected at endoscopies performed at St Vincents Hospital, Sydney, Australia. These were obtained from patients prospectively enrolled in an Australia-wide research collaboration entitled PROBE-NET: Progression of Barretts Esophagus to Esophageal Adenocarcinoma Network. The EAC specimens were either obtained from patients at St Vincents Hospital or the Department of Surgery at Flinders University, Adelaide, Australia. All cancer specimens were pre-treatment, biopsies from radio-chemotherapy naive patients. All tissue samples were collected from the tubular esophagus at or above the gastroesophageal junction, which was defined as the proximal border of the gastric rugal folds. In patients with BE or LGD, a columnar mucosal segment of at least 1 cm was required for inclusion in the present study. Prior to RNA isolation, histologic sections of all tissue specimens were reviewed by three experienced GI-pathologists to verify the correct diagnosis and determined tissue cellularity. Samples had to contain a minimum of 50% diagnosis defining specialized epithelium to be deemed suitable for RNA extraction. RNA extraction and quality control prior to cDNA library construction After tissue-homogenization using a Polytron Homogenizer PT 3100 (Thomas Scientific, Swedesboro, NJ) RNA extraction was performed using the QIAGEN RNeasy Mini Kit, (Cat #74104, QIAGEN, Valencia, CA) following the manufacturers protocol. RNA yield and quality was measured using a BioSpec nano spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Scientific Instruments, Sydney, Australia) and integrity was verified on a Bioanalyzer separation chip (Agilent Technologies, Forest Hill, Victoria, Australia). 260/280 ratios were > 2.0 for all cases and a minimum RNA Integrity Number (RIN) of 6 required for samples to be taken forward to library preparation for RNA sequencing. Median RNA yield per sample was 5.9 g (IQR 3.3 10.5g) with a median amount of RNA sequenced per sample being 3.3 g (2.1 4.0g). 500ng of total RNA was used as input material for library preparation using the TruSeq Stranded Total RNA Sample Prep Kit (Illumina, USA) according to manufacturers instructions. Individual libraries were indexed as recommended by Illumina. Indexed DNA libraries were analyzed individually using an Agilent Technologies 2100 Bioanalyzer with the DNA 1000 kit according to the manufacturers instructions (Agilent Technologies, USA). Libraries were diluted and pooled to a final concentration of 10 nM each in nuclease-free H2O (Ambion, USA). Pooled libraries were quantitated using a Life Technologies Qubit 2.0 Fluorometer with the Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit (Life Technologies, USA) and further diluted to 2 nM. Final DNA library concentration was confirmed using a Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit. PCR-competent library DNA concentration was verified using the universal KAPA Library Quantification Kit for Illumina Sequencing Platforms according to manufacturers instructions (KAPA Biosystems, USA). An Applied Biosystems 7900HT Fast Real-Time PCR machine (Life Technologies, USA) was used for quantitative real-time PCR.

In patients with BE or LGD, a columnar mucosal segment of at least 1 cm was required for inclusion in the present study. Prior to RNA isolation, histologic sections of all tissue specimens were reviewed by three experienced GI-pathologists to verify the correct diagnosis and determined tissue cellularity. Samples had to contain a minimum of 50% diagnosis defining specialized epithelium to be deemed suitable for RNA extraction. RNA extraction and quality control prior to cDNA library construction After tissue-homogenization using a Polytron Homogenizer PT 3100 (Thomas Scientific, Swedesboro, NJ) RNA extraction was performed using the QIAGEN RNeasy Mini Kit, (Cat #74104, QIAGEN, Valencia, CA) following the manufacturers protocol. RNA yield and quality was measured using a BioSpec nano spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Scientific Instruments, Sydney, Australia) and integrity was verified on a Bioanalyzer separation chip (Agilent Technologies, Forest Hill, Victoria, Australia). 260/280 ratios were > 2.0 for all cases and a minimum RNA Integrity Number (RIN) of 6 required for samples to be taken forward to library preparation for RNA sequencing. Median RNA yield per sample was 5.9 g (IQR 3.3 10.5g) with a median amount of RNA sequenced per sample being 3.3 g (2.1 4.0g). 500ng of total RNA was used as input material for library preparation using the TruSeq Stranded Total RNA Sample Prep Kit (Illumina, USA) according to manufacturers instructions. Individual libraries were indexed as recommended by Illumina. Indexed DNA libraries were analyzed individually using an Agilent Technologies 2100 Bioanalyzer with the DNA 1000 kit according to the manufacturers instructions (Agilent Technologies, USA). Libraries were diluted and pooled to a final concentration of 10 nM each in nuclease-free H2O (Ambion, USA). Pooled libraries were quantitated using a Life Technologies Qubit 2.0 Fluorometer with the Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit (Life Technologies, USA) and further diluted to 2 nM. Final DNA library concentration was confirmed using a Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit. PCR-competent library DNA concentration was verified using the universal KAPA Library Quantification Kit for Illumina Sequencing Platforms according to manufacturers instructions (KAPA Biosystems, USA). An Applied Biosystems 7900HT Fast Real-Time PCR machine (Life Technologies, USA) was used for quantitative real-time PCR.

All tissue samples were collected from the tubular esophagus at or above the gastroesophageal junction, which was defined as the proximal border of the gastric rugal folds. In patients with BE or LGD, a columnar mucosal segment of at least 1 cm was required for inclusion in the present study. Prior to RNA isolation, histologic sections of all tissue specimens were reviewed by three experienced GI-pathologists to verify the correct diagnosis and determined tissue cellularity. Samples had to contain a minimum of 50% diagnosis defining specialized epithelium to be deemed suitable for RNA extraction. RNA extraction and quality control prior to cDNA library construction After tissue-homogenization using a Polytron Homogenizer PT 3100 (Thomas Scientific, Swedesboro, NJ) RNA extraction was performed using the QIAGEN RNeasy Mini Kit, (Cat #74104, QIAGEN, Valencia, CA) following the manufacturers protocol. RNA yield and quality was measured using a BioSpec nano spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Scientific Instruments, Sydney, Australia) and integrity was verified on a Bioanalyzer separation chip (Agilent Technologies, Forest Hill, Victoria, Australia). 260/280 ratios were > 2.0 for all cases and a minimum RNA Integrity Number (RIN) of 6 required for samples to be taken forward to library preparation for RNA sequencing. Median RNA yield per sample was 5.9 g (IQR 3.3 10.5g) with a median amount of RNA sequenced per sample being 3.3 g (2.1 4.0g). 500ng of total RNA was used as input material for library preparation using the TruSeq Stranded Total RNA Sample Prep Kit (Illumina, USA) according to manufacturers instructions. Individual libraries were indexed as recommended by Illumina. Indexed DNA libraries were analyzed individually using an Agilent Technologies 2100 Bioanalyzer with the DNA 1000 kit according to the manufacturers instructions (Agilent Technologies, USA). Libraries were diluted and pooled to a final concentration of 10 nM each in nuclease-free H2O (Ambion, USA). Pooled libraries were quantitated using a Life Technologies Qubit 2.0 Fluorometer with the Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit (Life Technologies, USA) and further diluted to 2 nM. Final DNA library concentration was confirmed using a Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit. PCR-competent library DNA concentration was verified using the universal KAPA Library Quantification Kit for Illumina Sequencing Platforms according to manufacturers instructions (KAPA Biosystems, USA). An Applied Biosystems 7900HT Fast Real-Time PCR machine (Life Technologies, USA) was used for quantitative real-time PCR.

These were obtained from patients prospectively enrolled in an Australia-wide research collaboration entitled PROBE-NET: Progression of Barretts Esophagus to Esophageal Adenocarcinoma Network. The EAC specimens were either obtained from patients at St Vincents Hospital or the Department of Surgery at Flinders University, Adelaide, Australia. All cancer specimens were pre-treatment, biopsies from radio-chemotherapy naive patients. All tissue samples were collected from the tubular esophagus at or above the gastroesophageal junction, which was defined as the proximal border of the gastric rugal folds. In patients with BE or LGD, a columnar mucosal segment of at least 1 cm was required for inclusion in the present study. Prior to RNA isolation, histologic sections of all tissue specimens were reviewed by three experienced GI-pathologists to verify the correct diagnosis and determined tissue cellularity. Samples had to contain a minimum of 50% diagnosis defining specialized epithelium to be deemed suitable for RNA extraction. RNA extraction and quality control prior to cDNA library construction After tissue-homogenization using a Polytron Homogenizer PT 3100 (Thomas Scientific, Swedesboro, NJ) RNA extraction was performed using the QIAGEN RNeasy Mini Kit, (Cat #74104, QIAGEN, Valencia, CA) following the manufacturers protocol. RNA yield and quality was measured using a BioSpec nano spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Scientific Instruments, Sydney, Australia) and integrity was verified on a Bioanalyzer separation chip (Agilent Technologies, Forest Hill, Victoria, Australia). 260/280 ratios were > 2.0 for all cases and a minimum RNA Integrity Number (RIN) of 6 required for samples to be taken forward to library preparation for RNA sequencing. Median RNA yield per sample was 5.9 g (IQR 3.3 10.5g) with a median amount of RNA sequenced per sample being 3.3 g (2.1 4.0g). 500ng of total RNA was used as input material for library preparation using the TruSeq Stranded Total RNA Sample Prep Kit (Illumina, USA) according to manufacturers instructions. Individual libraries were indexed as recommended by Illumina. Indexed DNA libraries were analyzed individually using an Agilent Technologies 2100 Bioanalyzer with the DNA 1000 kit according to the manufacturers instructions (Agilent Technologies, USA). Libraries were diluted and pooled to a final concentration of 10 nM each in nuclease-free H2O (Ambion, USA). Pooled libraries were quantitated using a Life Technologies Qubit 2.0 Fluorometer with the Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit (Life Technologies, USA) and further diluted to 2 nM. Final DNA library concentration was confirmed using a Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit. PCR-competent library DNA concentration was verified using the universal KAPA Library Quantification Kit for Illumina Sequencing Platforms according to manufacturers instructions (KAPA Biosystems, USA). An Applied Biosystems 7900HT Fast Real-Time PCR machine (Life Technologies, USA) was used for quantitative real-time PCR.

library_construction_protocol: The NSq, BE, LGD tissue samples were collected at endoscopies performed at St Vincents Hospital, Sydney, Australia. These were obtained from patients prospectively enrolled in an Australia-wide research collaboration entitled PROBE-NET: Progression of Barretts Esophagus to Esophageal Adenocarcinoma Network. The EAC specimens were either obtained from patients at St Vincents Hospital or the Department of Surgery at Flinders University, Adelaide, Australia. All cancer specimens were pre-treatment, biopsies from radio-chemotherapy naive patients. All tissue samples were collected from the tubular esophagus at or above the gastroesophageal junction, which was defined as the proximal border of the gastric rugal folds. In patients with BE or LGD, a columnar mucosal segment of at least 1 cm was required for inclusion in the present study. Prior to RNA isolation, histologic sections of all tissue specimens were reviewed by three experienced GI-pathologists to verify the correct diagnosis and determined tissue cellularity. Samples had to contain a minimum of 50% diagnosis defining specialized epithelium to be deemed suitable for RNA extraction. RNA extraction and quality control prior to cDNA library construction After tissue-homogenization using a Polytron Homogenizer PT 3100 (Thomas Scientific, Swedesboro, NJ) RNA extraction was performed using the QIAGEN RNeasy Mini Kit, (Cat #74104, QIAGEN, Valencia, CA) following the manufacturers protocol. RNA yield and quality was measured using a BioSpec nano spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Scientific Instruments, Sydney, Australia) and integrity was verified on a Bioanalyzer separation chip (Agilent Technologies, Forest Hill, Victoria, Australia). 260/280 ratios were > 2.0 for all cases and a minimum RNA Integrity Number (RIN) of 6 required for samples to be taken forward to library preparation for RNA sequencing. Median RNA yield per sample was 5.9 g (IQR 3.3 10.5g) with a median amount of RNA sequenced per sample being 3.3 g (2.1 4.0g). 500ng of total RNA was used as input material for library preparation using the TruSeq Stranded Total RNA Sample Prep Kit (Illumina, USA) according to manufacturers instructions. Individual libraries were indexed as recommended by Illumina. Indexed DNA libraries were analyzed individually using an Agilent Technologies 2100 Bioanalyzer with the DNA 1000 kit according to the manufacturers instructions (Agilent Technologies, USA). Libraries were diluted and pooled to a final concentration of 10 nM each in nuclease-free H2O (Ambion, USA). Pooled libraries were quantitated using a Life Technologies Qubit 2.0 Fluorometer with the Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit (Life Technologies, USA) and further diluted to 2 nM. Final DNA library concentration was confirmed using a Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit. PCR-competent library DNA concentration was verified using the universal KAPA Library Quantification Kit for Illumina Sequencing Platforms according to manufacturers instructions (KAPA Biosystems, USA). An Applied Biosystems 7900HT Fast Real-Time PCR machine (Life Technologies, USA) was used for quantitative real-time PCR.
center_name: European Bioinformatics Institute;Garvan Institute of Medical Research

experiment_title: Illumina HiSeq 2500 paired end sequencing: Whole transcriptome profiling of Esophageal adenocarcinoma and Barrett's
study_title: Whole transcriptome profiling of Esophageal adenocarcinoma and Barrett's
sample_description: Protocols: The NSq, BE, LGD tissue samples were collected at endoscopies performed at St Vincents Hospital, Sydney, Australia. These were obtained from patients prospectively enrolled in an Australia-wide research collaboration entitled PROBE-NET: Progression of Barretts Esophagus to Esophageal Adenocarcinoma Network. The EAC specimens were either obtained from patients at St Vincents Hospital or the Department of Surgery at Flinders University, Adelaide, Australia. All cancer specimens were pre-treatment, biopsies from radio-chemotherapy naive patients. All tissue samples were collected from the tubular esophagus at or above the gastroesophageal junction, which was defined as the proximal border of the gastric rugal folds. In patients with BE or LGD, a columnar mucosal segment of at least 1 cm was required for inclusion in the present study. Prior to RNA isolation, histologic sections of all tissue specimens were reviewed by three experienced GI-pathologists to verify the correct diagnosis and determined tissue cellularity. Samples had to contain a minimum of 50% diagnosis defining specialized epithelium to be deemed suitable for RNA extraction. RNA extraction and quality control prior to cDNA library construction After tissue-homogenization using a Polytron Homogenizer PT 3100 (Thomas Scientific, Swedesboro, NJ) RNA extraction was performed using the QIAGEN RNeasy Mini Kit, (Cat #74104, QIAGEN, Valencia, CA) following the manufacturers protocol. RNA yield and quality was measured using a BioSpec nano spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Scientific Instruments, Sydney, Australia) and integrity was verified on a Bioanalyzer separation chip (Agilent Technologies, Forest Hill, Victoria, Australia). 260/280 ratios were > 2.0 for all cases and a minimum RNA Integrity Number (RIN) of 6 required for samples to be taken forward to library preparation for RNA sequencing. Median RNA yield per sample was 5.9 g (IQR 3.3 10.5g) with a median amount of RNA sequenced per sample being 3.3 g (2.1 4.0g). 500ng of total RNA was used as input material for library preparation using the TruSeq Stranded Total RNA Sample Prep Kit (Illumina, USA) according to manufacturers instructions. Individual libraries were indexed as recommended by Illumina. Indexed DNA libraries were analyzed individually using an Agilent Technologies 2100 Bioanalyzer with the DNA 1000 kit according to the manufacturers instructions (Agilent Technologies, USA). Libraries were diluted and pooled to a final concentration of 10 nM each in nuclease-free H2O (Ambion, USA). Pooled libraries were quantitated using a Life Technologies Qubit 2.0 Fluorometer with the Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit (Life Technologies, USA) and further diluted to 2 nM. Final DNA library concentration was confirmed using a Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit. PCR-competent library DNA concentration was verified using the universal KAPA Library Quantification Kit for Illumina Sequencing Platforms according to manufacturers instructions (KAPA Biosystems, USA). An Applied Biosystems 7900HT Fast Real-Time PCR machine (Life Technologies, USA) was used for quantitative real-time PCR.

An Applied Biosystems 7900HT Fast Real-Time PCR machine (Life Technologies, USA) was used for quantitative real-time PCR.
project_name: Whole transcriptome profiling of Esophageal adenocarcinoma and Barrett's
description: Illumina HiSeq 2500 paired end sequencing: Whole transcriptome profiling of Esophageal adenocarcinoma and Barrett's
library_construction_protocol: The NSq, BE, LGD tissue samples were collected at endoscopies performed at St Vincents Hospital, Sydney, Australia. These were obtained from patients prospectively enrolled in an Australia-wide research collaboration entitled PROBE-NET: Progression of Barretts Esophagus to Esophageal Adenocarcinoma Network. The EAC specimens were either obtained from patients at St Vincents Hospital or the Department of Surgery at Flinders University, Adelaide, Australia. All cancer specimens were pre-treatment, biopsies from radio-chemotherapy naive patients. All tissue samples were collected from the tubular esophagus at or above the gastroesophageal junction, which was defined as the proximal border of the gastric rugal folds. In patients with BE or LGD, a columnar mucosal segment of at least 1 cm was required for inclusion in the present study. Prior to RNA isolation, histologic sections of all tissue specimens were reviewed by three experienced GI-pathologists to verify the correct diagnosis and determined tissue cellularity. Samples had to contain a minimum of 50% diagnosis defining specialized epithelium to be deemed suitable for RNA extraction. RNA extraction and quality control prior to cDNA library construction After tissue-homogenization using a Polytron Homogenizer PT 3100 (Thomas Scientific, Swedesboro, NJ) RNA extraction was performed using the QIAGEN RNeasy Mini Kit, (Cat #74104, QIAGEN, Valencia, CA) following the manufacturers protocol. RNA yield and quality was measured using a BioSpec nano spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Scientific Instruments, Sydney, Australia) and integrity was verified on a Bioanalyzer separation chip (Agilent Technologies, Forest Hill, Victoria, Australia). 260/280 ratios were > 2.0 for all cases and a minimum RNA Integrity Number (RIN) of 6 required for samples to be taken forward to library preparation for RNA sequencing. Median RNA yield per sample was 5.9 g (IQR 3.3 10.5g) with a median amount of RNA sequenced per sample being 3.3 g (2.1 4.0g). 500ng of total RNA was used as input material for library preparation using the TruSeq Stranded Total RNA Sample Prep Kit (Illumina, USA) according to manufacturers instructions. Individual libraries were indexed as recommended by Illumina. Indexed DNA libraries were analyzed individually using an Agilent Technologies 2100 Bioanalyzer with the DNA 1000 kit according to the manufacturers instructions (Agilent Technologies, USA). Libraries were diluted and pooled to a final concentration of 10 nM each in nuclease-free H2O (Ambion, USA). Pooled libraries were quantitated using a Life Technologies Qubit 2.0 Fluorometer with the Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit (Life Technologies, USA) and further diluted to 2 nM. Final DNA library concentration was confirmed using a Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit. PCR-competent library DNA concentration was verified using the universal KAPA Library Quantification Kit for Illumina Sequencing Platforms according to manufacturers instructions (KAPA Biosystems, USA). An Applied Biosystems 7900HT Fast Real-Time PCR machine (Life Technologies, USA) was used for quantitative real-time PCR.

PCR-competent library DNA concentration was verified using the universal KAPA Library Quantification Kit for Illumina Sequencing Platforms according to manufacturers instructions (KAPA Biosystems, USA). An Applied Biosystems 7900HT Fast Real-Time PCR machine (Life Technologies, USA) was used for quantitative real-time PCR.
center_name: European Bioinformatics Institute;Garvan Institute of Medical Research

experiment_title: Illumina HiSeq 2500 paired end sequencing: Whole transcriptome profiling of Esophageal adenocarcinoma and Barrett's
study_title: Whole transcriptome profiling of Esophageal adenocarcinoma and Barrett's
sample_description: Protocols: The NSq, BE, LGD tissue samples were collected at endoscopies performed at St Vincents Hospital, Sydney, Australia. These were obtained from patients prospectively enrolled in an Australia-wide research collaboration entitled PROBE-NET: Progression of Barretts Esophagus to Esophageal Adenocarcinoma Network. The EAC specimens were either obtained from patients at St Vincents Hospital or the Department of Surgery at Flinders University, Adelaide, Australia. All cancer specimens were pre-treatment, biopsies from radio-chemotherapy naive patients. All tissue samples were collected from the tubular esophagus at or above the gastroesophageal junction, which was defined as the proximal border of the gastric rugal folds. In patients with BE or LGD, a columnar mucosal segment of at least 1 cm was required for inclusion in the present study. Prior to RNA isolation, histologic sections of all tissue specimens were reviewed by three experienced GI-pathologists to verify the correct diagnosis and determined tissue cellularity. Samples had to contain a minimum of 50% diagnosis defining specialized epithelium to be deemed suitable for RNA extraction. RNA extraction and quality control prior to cDNA library construction After tissue-homogenization using a Polytron Homogenizer PT 3100 (Thomas Scientific, Swedesboro, NJ) RNA extraction was performed using the QIAGEN RNeasy Mini Kit, (Cat #74104, QIAGEN, Valencia, CA) following the manufacturers protocol. RNA yield and quality was measured using a BioSpec nano spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Scientific Instruments, Sydney, Australia) and integrity was verified on a Bioanalyzer separation chip (Agilent Technologies, Forest Hill, Victoria, Australia). 260/280 ratios were > 2.0 for all cases and a minimum RNA Integrity Number (RIN) of 6 required for samples to be taken forward to library preparation for RNA sequencing. Median RNA yield per sample was 5.9 g (IQR 3.3 10.5g) with a median amount of RNA sequenced per sample being 3.3 g (2.1 4.0g). 500ng of total RNA was used as input material for library preparation using the TruSeq Stranded Total RNA Sample Prep Kit (Illumina, USA) according to manufacturers instructions. Individual libraries were indexed as recommended by Illumina. Indexed DNA libraries were analyzed individually using an Agilent Technologies 2100 Bioanalyzer with the DNA 1000 kit according to the manufacturers instructions (Agilent Technologies, USA). Libraries were diluted and pooled to a final concentration of 10 nM each in nuclease-free H2O (Ambion, USA). Pooled libraries were quantitated using a Life Technologies Qubit 2.0 Fluorometer with the Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit (Life Technologies, USA) and further diluted to 2 nM. Final DNA library concentration was confirmed using a Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit. PCR-competent library DNA concentration was verified using the universal KAPA Library Quantification Kit for Illumina Sequencing Platforms according to manufacturers instructions (KAPA Biosystems, USA). An Applied Biosystems 7900HT Fast Real-Time PCR machine (Life Technologies, USA) was used for quantitative real-time PCR.

Pooled libraries were quantitated using a Life Technologies Qubit 2.0 Fluorometer with the Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit (Life Technologies, USA) and further diluted to 2 nM. Final DNA library concentration was confirmed using a Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit. PCR-competent library DNA concentration was verified using the universal KAPA Library Quantification Kit for Illumina Sequencing Platforms according to manufacturers instructions (KAPA Biosystems, USA). An Applied Biosystems 7900HT Fast Real-Time PCR machine (Life Technologies, USA) was used for quantitative real-time PCR.

Indexed DNA libraries were analyzed individually using an Agilent Technologies 2100 Bioanalyzer with the DNA 1000 kit according to the manufacturers instructions (Agilent Technologies, USA). Libraries were diluted and pooled to a final concentration of 10 nM each in nuclease-free H2O (Ambion, USA). Pooled libraries were quantitated using a Life Technologies Qubit 2.0 Fluorometer with the Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit (Life Technologies, USA) and further diluted to 2 nM. Final DNA library concentration was confirmed using a Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit. PCR-competent library DNA concentration was verified using the universal KAPA Library Quantification Kit for Illumina Sequencing Platforms according to manufacturers instructions (KAPA Biosystems, USA). An Applied Biosystems 7900HT Fast Real-Time PCR machine (Life Technologies, USA) was used for quantitative real-time PCR.

experiment_title: Illumina HiSeq 2500 paired end sequencing: Whole transcriptome profiling of Esophageal adenocarcinoma and Barrett's
study_title: Whole transcriptome profiling of Esophageal adenocarcinoma and Barrett's
sample_description: Protocols: The NSq, BE, LGD tissue samples were collected at endoscopies performed at St Vincents Hospital, Sydney, Australia. These were obtained from patients prospectively enrolled in an Australia-wide research collaboration entitled PROBE-NET: Progression of Barretts Esophagus to Esophageal Adenocarcinoma Network. The EAC specimens were either obtained from patients at St Vincents Hospital or the Department of Surgery at Flinders University, Adelaide, Australia. All cancer specimens were pre-treatment, biopsies from radio-chemotherapy naive patients. All tissue samples were collected from the tubular esophagus at or above the gastroesophageal junction, which was defined as the proximal border of the gastric rugal folds. In patients with BE or LGD, a columnar mucosal segment of at least 1 cm was required for inclusion in the present study. Prior to RNA isolation, histologic sections of all tissue specimens were reviewed by three experienced GI-pathologists to verify the correct diagnosis and determined tissue cellularity. Samples had to contain a minimum of 50% diagnosis defining specialized epithelium to be deemed suitable for RNA extraction. RNA extraction and quality control prior to cDNA library construction After tissue-homogenization using a Polytron Homogenizer PT 3100 (Thomas Scientific, Swedesboro, NJ) RNA extraction was performed using the QIAGEN RNeasy Mini Kit, (Cat #74104, QIAGEN, Valencia, CA) following the manufacturers protocol. RNA yield and quality was measured using a BioSpec nano spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Scientific Instruments, Sydney, Australia) and integrity was verified on a Bioanalyzer separation chip (Agilent Technologies, Forest Hill, Victoria, Australia). 260/280 ratios were > 2.0 for all cases and a minimum RNA Integrity Number (RIN) of 6 required for samples to be taken forward to library preparation for RNA sequencing. Median RNA yield per sample was 5.9 g (IQR 3.3 10.5g) with a median amount of RNA sequenced per sample being 3.3 g (2.1 4.0g). 500ng of total RNA was used as input material for library preparation using the TruSeq Stranded Total RNA Sample Prep Kit (Illumina, USA) according to manufacturers instructions. Individual libraries were indexed as recommended by Illumina. Indexed DNA libraries were analyzed individually using an Agilent Technologies 2100 Bioanalyzer with the DNA 1000 kit according to the manufacturers instructions (Agilent Technologies, USA). Median RNA yield per sample was 5.9 g (IQR 3.3 10.5g) with a median amount of RNA sequenced per sample being 3.3 g (2.1 4.0g). 500ng of total RNA was used as input material for library preparation using the TruSeq Stranded Total RNA Sample Prep Kit (Illumina, USA) according to manufacturers instructions. Individual libraries were indexed as recommended by Illumina. Indexed DNA libraries were analyzed individually using an Agilent Technologies 2100 Bioanalyzer with the DNA 1000 kit according to the manufacturers instructions (Agilent Technologies, USA). Libraries were diluted and pooled to a final concentration of 10 nM each in nuclease-free H2O (Ambion, USA). Pooled libraries were quantitated using a Life Technologies Qubit 2.0 Fluorometer with the Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit (Life Technologies, USA) and further diluted to 2 nM. Final DNA library concentration was confirmed using a Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit. PCR-competent library DNA concentration was verified using the universal KAPA Library Quantification Kit for Illumina Sequencing Platforms according to manufacturers instructions (KAPA Biosystems, USA). An Applied Biosystems 7900HT Fast Real-Time PCR machine (Life Technologies, USA) was used for quantitative real-time PCR.

RNA extraction and quality control prior to cDNA library construction After tissue-homogenization using a Polytron Homogenizer PT 3100 (Thomas Scientific, Swedesboro, NJ) RNA extraction was performed using the QIAGEN RNeasy Mini Kit, (Cat #74104, QIAGEN, Valencia, CA) following the manufacturers protocol. RNA yield and quality was measured using a BioSpec nano spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Scientific Instruments, Sydney, Australia) and integrity was verified on a Bioanalyzer separation chip (Agilent Technologies, Forest Hill, Victoria, Australia). 260/280 ratios were > 2.0 for all cases and a minimum RNA Integrity Number (RIN) of 6 required for samples to be taken forward to library preparation for RNA sequencing. Median RNA yield per sample was 5.9 g (IQR 3.3 10.5g) with a median amount of RNA sequenced per sample being 3.3 g (2.1 4.0g). 500ng of total RNA was used as input material for library preparation using the TruSeq Stranded Total RNA Sample Prep Kit (Illumina, USA) according to manufacturers instructions. Individual libraries were indexed as recommended by Illumina. Indexed DNA libraries were analyzed individually using an Agilent Technologies 2100 Bioanalyzer with the DNA 1000 kit according to the manufacturers instructions (Agilent Technologies, USA). Libraries were diluted and pooled to a final concentration of 10 nM each in nuclease-free H2O (Ambion, USA). Pooled libraries were quantitated using a Life Technologies Qubit 2.0 Fluorometer with the Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit (Life Technologies, USA) and further diluted to 2 nM. Final DNA library concentration was confirmed using a Qubit dsDNA HS Assay Kit. PCR-competent library DNA concentration was verified using the universal KAPA Library Quantification Kit for Illumina Sequencing Platforms according to manufacturers instructions (KAPA Biosystems, USA). An Applied Biosystems 7900HT Fast Real-Time PCR machine (Life Technologies, USA) was used for quantitative real-time PCR.

project_name: Homo sapiens
description: Illumina HiSeq 2500 sequencing: GSM2477948: EAC RNA-Seq #1 Homo sapiens RNA-Seq

experiment_title: NextSeq 500 sequencing: GSM5283361: OAC44N Homo sapiens RNA-Seq
study_title: Single Cell RNA sequencing (DropSeq) of esophageal adenocarcinoma and matched normal samples
project_name: Single Cell RNA sequencing (DropSeq) of esophageal adenocarcinoma and matched normal samples
description: NextSeq 500 sequencing: GSM5283361: OAC44N Homo sapiens RNA-Seq
library_construction_protocol: Samples were relocated to the laboratory and placed in a tissue culture hood, moved to a petri dish and washed with PBS-A and then minced with a scalpel to approximately 1mm chunks. Minced tissue was transferred to a 50ml Falcon tube with 5ml of DMEM complete 100 ul of 150 U/ml Collagenase P and 100 ul of10 mg/ml DNase. The samples were placed in an incubator at 37o C with agitation for 60 minutes and disturbed at 15 minutes and 30 minutes with pipettes. Samples were then passed through a 70 um strainer and 10 ml of empty DMEM added. Cells were then pelleted using centrifugation and media aspirated. Cells were resuspended in RBC lysis solution and incubated at 4oC for 10 minutes, 10 ml of empty DMEM was added and the suspension was passed through a 40 um strainer before being pelleted and resuspended in either 1 ml PBS or 1 ml of cell suspension buffer. 10 ul of cells in suspension and 10 ul of trypan blue was mixed together and cells were counted on a C-chip Fuchs-Rosenthal haemocytometer. A 150,000-cell aliquot was made up to 1.5 mls with cell suspension buffer and prepared for DropSeq. scRNA-seq
